text:
[Section: Page 803 of 1048]



Message 3024 of 4024
Hey-
I don't want to escalate this any further than you already have by emailing me with Natalie CC'd. You know she has sent numerous messages to Lisa
about pursuing legal action against me if I do anything that violates your admittedly wrong RO. That feels like an attempt to get me to do that.
This whole thing boils down to the fact that you are taking a statement by me so literally that it's counterproductive. You secretly took $10k from an
account where I said the money was earmarked. I responded by saying I don't do that to our BofA account so you could manage bills.
In response, you've gone through and picked out my grocery bills at Safeway, a $300 withdrawal, and a single bill pay to create some false equivalency
as if you're catching me out. Then used that to ask me If the activity was fraud. I confirmed below that no action was necessary from you.
So, from my perspective, it feels like you're playing games. Between the email with Natalie CC'd, ignoring the fact that I said no action is necessary
below, and the comparison between my grocery shopping at Safeway and you taking $10k, I feel like you are harassing me now.
I also sent an OFW message earlier today asking that we stand down as we are too triggered, and it would be counterproductive. You agreed but then
doubled down 'off platform.' I don't know how to work with you, Christine. Please consider a more constructive way for us to collaborate.
-robert
Sent:06/05/2024 at 04:04 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 06/05/2024 at 06:00 PM)
Subject:Re: Visa Card
Message 3025 of 4024
Are we good here? The lack of acknowledgment to the answer you keep chasing me for feels intentional. Is there even the smallest effort you can
make?
Sent:06/05/2024 at 06:16 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 06/05/2024 at 07:47 PM)
Subject:Re: Visa Card
Message 3026 of 4024
To solve the grocery money caper, 13 messages were swapped here and three on email. When I proposed our truce, I asked we put those disagreements
aside and focus on this one issue.
I haven't heard back from you in over 12 hours. Please don't make your issue Adrian's issue. I saw him on T-Day, Christmas, and many times since.
I'd like to see him for his birthday, even briefly.
Please let me know how I can see the child that I delivered 12 years ago, was called mini-me till you did this, and whom I have had endless capers with.
I am a part of him and always will be.
Please let me know how to work with you to make it happen subject to your rules.
Sent:06/05/2024 at 07:12 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 06/05/2024 at 07:47 PM)
Subject:Re: Adrian's Birthday

So you knew his birthday was coming. It happens on an annual basis. You knew I was going to ask I have done it for each one of my children.
When we make alternate dates, you screw me. Like when you hadnChristmas Eve and I had Christmas Day, but then you really had Christmas day.

see my son for his birthday. Surely you knew that was coming.
Sent:06/05/2024 at 08:07 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 06/05/2024 at 10:07 PM)
Subject:Re: Adrian's Birthday
Message 3036 of 4024
We were having an active discussion back-and-forth and you just walked away.
A minimum if you’re going to block me from my youngest child on his birthday, I would like to work with you to craft joint messaging so I do not
make you look bad. I’m not gonna say anything negative. I never do. But I would like to at least explain what we will be doing in the future as a make
up for this. So that’s where I need your help.
Obviously, I will be talking to him tomorrow since it’s his birthday and you won’t allow me to see him. Please consider his feelings and respond in a
timely way so we speak with one voice and don’t put him in the middle. I avoid that at all costs because that makes him hate himself and consider self
harm, as we have seen recently.

Makes sense. Thank you.
In that context, can we explore the communication protocols suggested four months ago, like allowing us to share things and have updates or decision
discussions via email?
We are just trashing our relationship by putting artificial barriers to collaboration in place. I can say the same thing here as I can there, so there really is
no reason to make things so divisive and impossible on purpose.
Sent:06/06/2024 at 10:53 AM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 06/06/2024 at 02:38 PM)
Subject:Re: OFW Communications

And if the only reason is that you can send OFW messages to Natalie, it's frankly bunk. All you have to do is hit -> Print -> To PDF -> Attach and
send to Natiale. It's the same thing, even the same number of steps.
We do so many things that make our life and ability to work together intentionally impossible that it does not make sense. Plus we have agreed to the
common sense changes on at least ~5 occasions in the past.
Message 3042 of 4024
It’s just your jam to not reply to anything I suggest to help be more constructive.
Instead it seems like you prefer to just fuel the fire by not even bothering to respond.
I can’t imagine what it’s like in your head with so much hate and drive to destroy me.
I wish you nothing but the best if for no other reason than limiting collateral damage.

I’ll assume you don’t believe I get those anymore but I think a parenting plan may say otherwise.
As my co-parent I hope you investigate if what you are doing is healthy for them long term.
I’d like to at least drop off his gift tomorrow. I think that is the very least you should permit.
Please advise.

It is healthy for him to see I care about him. I am 50% of him and when you teach him to hate me, you teach him to hate himself. Please let me know. I
can meet you as you go to the play date or after your workout if that makes it easier. This is a reasonable ask.

happen.

From:Robert Moyer

He has been great with me and when with his friends.
I will ask why he gets distressed.
Sent:06/09/2024 at 10:20 AM
From:Christine Moyer
To:Robert Moyer (First Viewed: 06/09/2024 at 10:21 AM)
Subject:Re: OFW Communications

Message 3072 of 4024
I want to clarify that I didn’t say my communications with Adrian caused him distress. I mentioned it was an emotional situation covering a range of
feelings, not distress. If you identify anything contrary, please highlight it rather than just say it to create a narrative.
I agree working with a counselor on child-related matters would be great. I hope we can take their advice seriously moving forward rather than using
the internet and lawyers for guidance. It’s important for Adrian to feel supported without being caught in the middle of our issues.
I also wouldn’t expect Adrian to feel uncomfortable with either of us. It’s unfair to assume emotions are caused by just one parent without looking at
the big picture. To explain, I'd start with "Divorce poison: How to protect your family from bad-mouthing and brainwashing."
And before we forget what the title of the tread is, let’s figure out a communication plan that keeps both of us informed about our children's well-
being. I'm not comfortable with your presumed sole custody absent due process and want an effective channel to co-parent safely.
Sent:06/09/2024 at 10:57 AM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 06/09/2024 at 04:10 PM)
Subject:Re: OFW Communications
Message 3073 of 4024
Sounds like you don’t read visitation reports.
Sharing again here to help you find in email.
I’d encourage you to follow along on these.

FYI, the latest visitation report from Alan for Adrian and I is attached. We had an excellent time as always.
During our last visit, Adrian was really focused on making sure his room was ready here, as we had put it off in the past given our circumstances. We
spent about an hour and a half getting it set up, which wasn’t mentioned in the last report. The first thing he did when he arrived was run downstairs
to check if everything was still good to go, and it was.This is important to him.
Later, we looked through pictures on my phone since all the family photos had been removed from his house. I did this to show him that he comes
from
a place of love and ensure that we are all included in the pictures. We had a great time reminiscing, and Adrian enjoyed telling "his own stories" behind
the pictures. I texted him the slideshow so he could
keep those memories close and promised more.
Instead of our usual action movie, Adrian wanted to watch "IF," a childhood movie about a 12-year-old who keeps a picture of them and their parents
from better times. The story is about not losing a parent and honoring family memories. It was incredibly poignant and hit close to home.
Fortunately, the movie had a happy ending with the child reuniting with their dad. Talk about a tear-jerker.
Adrian's last two basketball games were tough, with emotional meltdowns. This time, I was able to spend time with him beforehand. He really
enjoyed
the game, was happy, laughing, and during the game, he came off the bench and said, "Nothing is wrong, Dad. I just wanted to tell you how much I
love you." For a 12-year-old boy, doing that in front of his team was a big deal to me. A WOW moment.
Sent:06/09/2024 at 02:52 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 06/09/2024 at 04:10 PM)
Subject:Re: OFW Communications

I am grateful Adrian got an opportunity to remember what we truly were for a bit. Even if Christine and I disagree on adult issues, he sees nothing
but love and support for what we were as a family. The visits gives him time, space, and permission to honor the part of himself that he has lost
touch with. Lots of laughs, wrestling, and healthy teasing made us feel normal for a few hours.
Message 3074 of 4024
Yes I read Alan’s reports.
